channel.title: INtopBackup
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from INtopBackup, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Martin Luther King III, Martin Luther King Jr.'s son, reflects on his father's legacy

item.title: Trump has rolled out many of the Project 2025 policies he once claimed ignorance about
item.description: Some of the 2025 policies that have been implemented include cracking down on immigration and dismantling the Department of Education.

item.title: Martin Luther King Jr. would be inspired by today's activism, author says

item.title: Ecstasy and now a day off - Senegal fans around the world celebrate Afcon win
item.description: Senegal supporters have been partying after their team grabbed a dramatic 1-0 win over Morocco.

item.title: What's open and closed on Martin Luther King Jr. Day 2026?
item.description: Most stores on Monday are open during their regular business hours on Martin Luther King Jr. Day, with a few exceptions.

item.title: Japan PM Takaichi calls snap election three months after taking office
item.description: Sanae Takaichi, who took office office last October, hopes the vote will give her a stronger mandate.

item.title: Shark mauls surfer in Sydney day after boy bitten, critically injured
item.description: A surfer was attacked one day after a large shark bit a 12-year-old boy in the legs, leaving him fighting for survival in a hospital.

item.title: Trump links Greenland dispute to not getting Nobel Peace Prize
item.description: The US president says he no longer feels obliged to think only of peace, after not being awarded the annual prize.

item.title: Factory explosion in China kills four, injures 84
item.description: The blast caused noticeable tremors in the area and sent large plumes of smoke into the sky.

item.title: Hundreds of soldiers on standby for possible deployment to Minneapolis amid protests
item.description: About 1,500 active-duty soldiers are on standby in Alaska for possible deployment to Minneapolis, a U.S. defense official told CBS News Saturday.

Sending soldiers to Minneapolis for immigration crackdown would be unconstitutional, mayor says
item.description: Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey says sending active duty soldiers to Minnesota for an immigration crackdown is ridiculous and unconstitutional.
